newsitem.title: GERMANY: FOCUS-Bid to solve German metal pay row collapses.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS-Bid to solve German metal pay row collapses.

text.p: Germany's metal and engineering industry on Friday moved one step closer to possible all-out strikes after an attempt by regional negotiators to solve a bitter dispute over proposed cuts to labour costs collapsed.

There had been hopes that union leaders and employers in the state of Baden-Wuerttemberg, home to Daimler-Benz AG's Mercedes car-making unit, might come to a deal that could then be used as a "pilot" agreement for other regions.

But leaders of the IG Metall trade union said after the 19-hour talks broke down early on Friday that employers had continued to demand cuts to sick pay entitlements, an issue on which they were not ready to negotiate.
"The employers must finally realise that no deal can be struck with IG Metall that is to the detriment of those workers who fall ill," IG Metall deputy chairman Walter Riester told journalists.

Dieter Hundt, chief negotiator for the Gesamtmetall metal and engineering employers federation, attacked IG Metall for showing "no willingness for agreement". Employers are seeking an overall freeze in labour costs in 1997.
The talks followed the failure last month of attempts to find a national agreement over planned cuts to sick pay and other worker benefits such as holiday and Christmas bonuses.

A union spokeswoman confirmed the two sides had now agreed to hold further talks this month in the state of North-Rhine Westphalia in what is likely to be the last chance to solve the row on labour costs before the main 1997 wage round in January.

If no overall agreement is reached in Germany's major steel-producing region, union leaders could decide to follow a decision made by Bavarian worker representatives in September to cancel existing wage contracts.

Regional union chiefs there gave notice of their intention to cancel existing wage contracts from January 31, allowing the 650,000 engineering workers in the southern state to stage all-out strikes from March onwards.

Such a development could be disastrous for employers, which have already suffered wild-cat protests involving hundreds of thousands of workers against earlier attempts by firms including Daimler to impose a new law cutting sick pay from the current 100 percent of salary to 80 percent.

Gesamtmetall's Hundt said employers had in the latest talks offered to continue paying full sick entitlements in return for employees losing 1.7 days of holiday for each three weeks of absence -- something that was also rejected by the union.
The only area of agreement reached in the talks was in job protection measures that form part of IG Metall's 1997 wage demand.
The union agreed that in future companies suffering from a business downturn would be able to cut working hours with a proportional reduction in wages.
In return workers councils would seek a commitment from employers to prevent redundancies.
